page.title: 05Ladock River 2
page.content: The flat fields between the A39 road and the river form the flood plain of the Tresillian River. Rosehill Cottage gardens are full of flowers and vegetables because of the warm sheltered land and the damp, fertile soil. By the old toll road are some huge ash trees. They were growing so tall because it is sheltered and the trees do not get bent or blown down as in many parts of Cornwall. Some of the flood plain meadows are cut for silage, others are full of weeds and old cars, but the last two are cultivated for a market garden. On the right of the toll road the land slopes steeply upwards. Much of this is grassland but some is scrub. Down the valley at Cuskayne corner the County Council dumped tons of earth because the A39 is cracking. When it has settled a new road will be made.
